newsitem.title: USA: Lear to buy Keiper Car Seating.
newsitem.headline: Lear to buy Keiper Car Seating.

text.p: Lear Corp. said Tuesday it has a definitive agreement to acquire the equity and partnership interests in Keiper Car Seating GmbH & Co. for 400 million marks or about $235 million.
The stakes are being sold by Putsch GmbH & Co. KG, Keiper GmbH & Co. and certain affiliates.
Lear said the deal will significantly enhance its position as the world's largest independent manufacturer of seat systems, with sales of over $6.2 billion last year.

Keiper Car Seating develops, produces and supplies automotive vehicle seat systems on a just-in-time basis for markets in Germany, Brazil, Italy and South Africa. Its customers include Mercedes Benz, Audi and Volkswagen.
Keiper Car Seating had sales of about $615 million in 1996 and has more than 2,000 employees.

"The acquisition of Keiper Car Seating significantly strengthens our global growth opportunities and simultaneously enhances our relationships with some of Europe's leading automotive manufacturers," Lear Chairman Kenneth Way said in a statement.
Putsch said the sale followed an extensive evaluation of strategic options open to the German company.
Consummation of the transaction is subject to clearance by the Antitrust Commission of the European Union.
Lear, based in Southfield, Mich., has about 45,000 employees in over 140 facilities in 22 countries.
Lear's stock was unchanged at $37 early on the New York Stock Exchange.
